The mentor reduction (Dutch: mentorkorting) is a reduction in the contributions to the National Social Security Office (NSSO) for employers who organise workplace training, using one or more experienced employees as mentor or trainer. It concerns training for specific target groups of employees, e.g. trainees from full-time secondary education, young people with an apprenticeship contract or secondary school teachers doing a work placement.

By reducing the NSSO contributions, the authorities want to encourage employers to open up their companies or institutions to workplace training. In this way, they help reduce the unqualified outflow from education and offer young job seekers further training.

Het gaat om opleidingen voor bepaalde specifieke doelgroepen van werknemers, bijvoorbeeld stagiairs uit het voltijds secundair onderwijs, jongeren met een leerovereenkomst of leerkrachten uit het secundair onderwijs die een praktijkstage lopen.

Werkgevers uit zowel de openbare als de privésector komen in aanmerking.

  • in zijn onderneming of instelling stages of opleidingen laten plaatsvinden voor leerlingen/cursisten/stagiairs die tot de beoogde doelgroepen behoren
  • een of meer van zijn werknemers (de ‘mentoren’) belasten met de begeleiding van die stages of opleidingen.

beschrijving.en:
Employers from both the public and private sectors are eligible.

  • provide traineeships or training for pupils/course participants/trainees belonging to the intended target groups in their company or institution
  • entrust one or several of their employees (the 'mentors') with the supervision of said traineeships or training.

The precise criteria to be met by the different categories of persons undergoing training and the mentors can be found on the website.

beschrijving.en:
Employers

Any employer in the private and public sector (including non-profit organisations) who hires an employee at a place of business in the Flemish Region is eligible for the subsidy.

Employers of companies in difficulty are not eligible.

Employees

The employee must at the same time:

  • have been registered with VDAB as a non-working job seeker for at least 2 years upon entry into employment. Periods of short employment (less than three months), incapacity for work or imprisonment may be equated with periods as a job seeker.
  • be aged 25 or older and under 56 at the end of the quarter of entry into employment,
  • be granted an employment contract of indefinite duration, or equivalent (temporary employment contracts of at least 3 months are also eligible, if they are customary in the company's recruitment policy).
  • be working at a place of business in the Flemish Region
  • have an employment contract that took effect no earlier than 1 January 2017.

Not eligible: employees with a:

  • temporary employment contract
  • contract as a flexi-job employee
  • contract as a casual employee

The recruitment incentive cannot be combined with:

  • the salary incentive in the context of supported employment (sheltered and social workshops)
  • the remuneration in the context of local service economy
  • the salary incentive in the context of insertion companies (Dutch: invoegbedrijven).

The recruitment incentive can only be applied for online. You can do this via the e-desk of the Department of Work and Social Economy.

Each company or organisation shall decide who shall access the application on behalf of the organisation. When you apply for the incentive for the first time, you will first need to go through a login procedure. There is a separate procedure for

  • profit and non-profit companies and for federal government organisations and services
  • Flemish government organisations and for the education sector.

Application deadline

In principle, the incentive must be applied for online within 3 months of entry into employment.

beschrijving.en:
Payment

The employer receives the recruitment incentive in two instalments:

  • a first instalment of maximum EUR 1,250, when the employee has worked for the company for three months
  • a second instalment of maximum EUR 3,000, when the employee has worked for the company for one year.

Part-time employment

  • If the employee works less than 30%, no subsidy will be granted.
  • If the employee works between 30% and 80%, the subsidy will be 60% of the maximum (EUR 750 for the first instalment and EUR 1,800 for the second).
  • If the employee works more than 80%, the employer will receive the maximum subsidy.

The first subsidies have been paid since 10 October 2017.

beschrijving.en:
The mentor reduction (Dutch: mentorkorting) is a reduction in the contributions to the National Social Security Office (NSSO) for employers who organise workplace training, using one or more experienced employees as mentor or trainer. It concerns training for specific target groups of employees, e.g. trainees from full-time secondary education, young people with an apprenticeship contract or secondary school teachers doing a work placement.

By reducing the NSSO contributions, the authorities want to encourage employers to open up their companies or institutions to workplace training. In this way, they help reduce the unqualified outflow from education and offer young job seekers further training.

In principe kan elke onderneming een dienstencheque-onderneming worden mits het bekomen van een erkenning. Zowel commerciële ondernemingen als vzw’s en OCMW’s kunnen een erkenning aanvragen. Na het bekomen van de erkenning kunt u werknemers die als dienstenchequewerknemer willen werken aanwerven. Dat mogen ook buitenlandse werknemers zijn, op voorwaarde dat ze een geldige arbeidskaart hebben. Deze werknemers moeten eveneens aan enkele voorwaarden voldoen. beschrijving.en:
In principle, any company can become a service voucher company provided that it obtains recognition. Commercial enterprises as well as non-profit organisations and public social welfare centres can apply for recognition. Your company can either carry out activities exclusively with service vouchers or in addition to other activities.

In order to become a recognised company, you must meet a number of conditions. For example, you must take part in an information session, pay a deposit of EUR 25,000 and add an accurate business plan in accordance with the regulations on service vouchers. General conditions also apply.

After obtaining recognition, you have to recruit employees who want to work as service voucher employees. They may also be foreign workers, provided they have a valid work permit. These employees must also meet certain conditions. Certain categories of employees may not be recruited through a service voucher employment contract. In addition, they may only perform a specific number of defined tasks.
